class Parameter[source]

Parameter(values, name=None, default_value=None)

Base class for parameter.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class OrderedParameter[source]

OrderedParameter(values, name=None, default_value=None) :: Parameter

Base class for parameter that is ordered, such as numerical parameters.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class IntegerParameter[source]

IntegerParameter(values, name=None, default_value=None) :: OrderedParameter

Integer pramameter with a range.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
intp = IntegerParameter([0, 10])
assert intp.get_value(0.53) == 5
assert intp.is_valid(-2.3) is False
assert intp.is_valid(10.3, fix=True)==10
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class InListNumericParameter[source]

InListNumericParameter(values, name=None, default_value=None) :: OrderedParameter

Numerical pramameter with a known set of values, and the values are ordered. Otherwise, it becomes a categorical parameter.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
inlistp = InListNumericParameter(range(30))
assert inlistp.get_value(0.5) == 15
inlistp.get_rand_value()
assert inlistp.is_valid(-2.3) is False
assert inlistp.is_valid(10.3, fix=True)==11
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class FloatParameter[source]

FloatParameter(values, name=None, default_value=None) :: OrderedParameter

Floating number parameter with a range.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
floatp = FloatParameter([0, 10])
assert np.isclose(floatp.get_value(0.53), 5.3)
assert floatp.is_valid(-2.3) is False
assert floatp.is_valid(10.3, fix=True)==10
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class LogFloatParameter[source]

LogFloatParameter(values, name=None, default_value=None) :: OrderedParameter

Floating number parameter with a range, but the sampling is in a logrithmic scale. So lower paramter range is sampled more frequentyly than higher range.

  • Note: the parameter range must be positive, as log of negative number is not a real number.
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
logp = LogFloatParameter([1, 100])
assert logp.get_value(0.5) == 10
assert logp.is_valid(-2.3) is False
assert logp.is_valid(103, fix=True)==100
logp.get_rand_value(1, 10)

2.3635044254532342
{% endraw %}

LogFloatParameter samples values uniformly in a log scale. The upper and lower bounds should both be positive. The lower end will be sampled more than the higher end, as shown below:

{% raw %} 
plot(sorted([logp.get_rand_value() for i in range(1000)]))

[<matplotlib.lines.Line2D at 0x7f6d5393a898>]
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class CategoricalParameter[source]

CategoricalParameter(values, name=None, default_value=None) :: Parameter

Categorical parameter

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
catp = CategoricalParameter(['a', 'b', 'c'])
assert catp.get_rand_value() in ['a', 'b', 'c']
assert catp.is_valid('dd') is False
assert catp.is_valid('a')
assert catp.is_valid(103, fix=True) in 'abc'
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class CallableParameter[source]

CallableParameter(values, name=None, default_value=None) :: Parameter

The values of the parameter is a callable. When execute the values attribute, the callable will return the possible value of the parameter.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
callp = CallableParameter(partial(randn, 100, 1))
callp.get_rand_value()

99.48503232417154
{% endraw %}

How to use these parameter classes

In short, because __next__ method is defined for the parameter classes, it can be treat as a generator. A typical example of these classes can be as follows:

{% raw %} 
params = [LogFloatParameter([0.1,1000],'C'),
          CategoricalParameter(['poly', 'rbf', 'sigmoid'],"kernel"),
          LogFloatParameter([1e-6,1e6],'gamma')
         ]
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
{p.name:next(p) for p in params}

{'C': 0.13508941788902232, 'kernel': 'poly', 'gamma': 0.00024660837553032265}
{% endraw %}
